summary: In an antique shop, light from an old chest strikes young Ethan (Jason Behr). Amazed, owner Jack (Robert Forster) tells Ethan he now carries the spirit of a warrior who battled dragons in 16th-century Korea -- and one day he'll find a tattooed girl carrying the spirit of that warrior's beloved. Years later Ethan is working as a reporter when he meets tattooed Sarah (Amanda Brooks). Soon after, dragons descend on Los Angeles seeking out the two souls of the ancient lovers.

(maybe around the half of his participation was in Ethan's flashback at the beginning); they don't mention how did Sarah realised about everything (literally, Ethan went to meet her at the hospital and she didn't know/remember anything and, in the next scene, she magically knows almost everything that's going on); was the whole movie just to get to the point where the good reptile becomes a real dragon kills the other one and leaves with the sphere? just that?; does Ethan just walks back home at the end? 
From my point of view, I'd say it could've been a great movie (as I said, I believe that the plot's main idea was good), but they just wasted it (I mean, they could've expanded more things and correct the plot holes)

I am a big fan of enjoying bad movies for their cheese factor, but let me be straight: this movie is not bad in the fun way. It is just deeply, deeply tedious. Even by big dumb blockbuster standards, the script is extremely generic (flat characters in particular are one of my biggest peeves in movies and TV), and even during the climactic battles it's still no more entertaining than any of its dialogue scenes, which I can assure you are anything but.

People seem to praise the special effects, but I have to disagree. While the CGI monsters themselves are very well made, the actual compositing (the integration of the CGI into the live action footage, as well as greenscreen work) is terribly done, resulting in the monsters often looking poorly pasted on top of the picture and not at all like they're actually there.  

Unless you are wowed by the special effects, this movie has little to offer. It's too terrible to be enjoyed by its own merits, and too tedious and generic to be enjoyed ironically. Don't waste your time.

"Dragon Wars" a.k.a. "D-War" is a pretty lousy movie, but at least it's got one thing going for it: Dragons! It's the story of Ethan Kendrick (Jason Behr). He's the reincarnation of a man who, 500 years ago was charged with protecting a princess from the evil Buraki, a giant serpent. The woman in question, has been reincarnated as Sarah (Amanda Brooks). The young woman contains the essence of the Yeouiju, which can transform a serpent like Buraki (an Imugi) into a Celestial Drago, but only when she turns 20. It's nearing Sarah's birthday and Buraki sends his army of dinosaurs, dragons and soldiers to go get her! Ethan must save Sarah or she will be instrument in the destruction of our world... or whatever consequences Buraki transforming into a dragon will have.
When this movie features the dragons, it's awesome. There is a nice variety in the creatures that attack the humans and we get two good, long scenes featuring them. There is one scene in the past, where they simply annihilate the village where the past lives of Sarah and Ethan are living and one in the present where they battle helicopters, tanks and soldiers. We've got soldiers riding velociraptor-like dinosaurs, we've got two-legged Blastoise-like monster with cannons on their backs, we've got flying dragons and sword-wielding ground troops. The battle sequences with these guys are really awesome and the special effects are top-notch. We also get some cool moments where the evil Buraki goes on a rampage in present day. The scenes where it is slithering across crowded streets, knocking hundreds of cars over, crawling over buildings, encircling skyscrapers in its coils and eating people is truly awesome. We even get a pretty sweet Imugi vs. Imugi battle and a dragon vs. Imugi fight towards the end of the movie. If you just like seeing giant monsters wrecking stuff, there's a lot to like here.
Whenever there are only people talking in the movie, without any dragons anywhere near them, it's downright terrible. This is the kind of movie where characters really under-react to the destruction that's around them. Craig Robinson in particular looks really unenthusiastic, even when being chased by a towering serpent capable of reducing buildings to dust. You can tell no one's priorities were in any of the scenes were people are acting too, because for no discernible reason, no one ever sees the monster moving as long as it's off-screen and every single person in the world, except for that one comedic guy no one believes, is fast-asleep whenever the monsters show up. Even from an overall story level though, this is really bad. The climax of the movie gets resolved in a Deus-Ex Machina that really cheapens the movie and makes it obvious that writer/director Shim Hyung-rae wrote himself into a corner and had no idea what to do with his own story. The movie becomes really laughable in hindsight because you realize if a character in the past hadn't been a total moron, the whole situation could have been avoided and millions of lives would have been spared. 
What this movie has going for it is the laughable storyline, which includes flashbacks within flashbacks, a confusing story that's just an excuse to tie in scenes of monsters wrecking civilizations together and a half-dozen clunky moments of characters interacting with each other that will leave you scratching your head in confusion. The special effects are good and pretty exciting, but the story sucks. That means the movie is great for making fun of and makes for a great background movie at your party. When people are talking your guests can either laugh or ignore the movie. When the dragons start wrecking the place, it'll make for great conversation. I say rent "D-War" (I think that title is so nutty it's awesome) on Blu-ray, watch it with your buddies that want to have some laughs and you'll have a good time. (On Blu-ray, June 20, 2014)

Dragon Wars Movie Review 

	An ancient evil awakens in Dragon Wars where Los Angeles becomes a battleground of havoc and destruction. Image a 200-meter-long evil serpent from ancient Korea with an army of giant lizards, flying dragons, black-armoured humanoid warriors, and immense reptiles. A spectacular and dynamic action-packed display of computer-generated imagery (CGI) awaits you in Dragon Wars!

	According to a Korean legend, long ago there lived great serpents called Imoogies. They lived in the heavens with their legions of followers. Every 500 years one Imoogi is rewarded for its good deeds with a chance to become a Celestial Dragon. The Imoogi needs to receive from heaven the gift of the Yuh Yi Joo. It is the strength and power of the Yuh Yi Joo that allows an Imoogi to transform into a dragon. One evil serpent, Buraki, wanted to possess Yuh Yi Joo; heaven would not allow it and so hid the Yuh Yi Joo on Earth. Heaven sent down its best warriors, Haram and his master Bochun, to protect the Yuh Yi Joo. A female named Narin was born with Yuh Yi Joo which would become completely formed when she reached 20. This is when the evil Buraki and his followers attacked the village searching for Narin who was saved by Haram. Defying the rule of heaven he threw away a special pendent and ran away with Narin. With Buraki still in pursuit they jumped off a cliff and died. Now, 500 years later Bochun, Haram and Narin are reincarnated in present day Los Angeles. Bochun/Jack finds Haram/Ethan and gives him the pendant who finds Narin/Sarah the day she turns 20. Buraki and his army attack the city wreaking havoc and destruction in their quest to find Sarah. Haram/ Ethan gets a second chance to protect the Yuh Yi Joo.

	The director of this fantastic action fantasy B film, Hyung Rae Shim, did an excellent job bringing this legend to life. He used flashbacks to tell the original story so we can predict the destruction coming to LA. It took Shim five years to make the most expensive and elaborate film in Korean history, creating a familiar atmosphere for international audiences. His direction demonstrated good timing, technical and artistic techniques.

	The qualities of the visual effects are astounding and extraordinary. A director must image everything he cannot see when shooting a film. To accomplish this, Shim built his own special effects studio, Young Gu Art, to create the CGI. The battle scenes are complex and realistic. Wave after wave of continuous heart-pounding action keeps you enthralled.

	I really admire Shim for the fantastic technical effects he accomplished and increasing the reputation of the Korean film industry. He took a big risk making this film and I believe that it will stand the test of time. Dragons are good for films. Period.

Believe me, there's plenty of bad things you can say about the Korean import called "Dragon Wars", but to start with, I'd like to accentuate the positive. This is a very ambitious, good-looking movie that never lets its modest budget show. The battle scenes that permeate the second half of this picture are exciting, well directed and a lot of fun.
You only wish that the writers didn't take so long to set-up those wars. That set-up is a tedious, boring and laugh-filled mess. After a half hour of ridiculous explanations and contrived dialogue, you're ready to scream "Enough!" at the screen. Everything is as clear as mud, but once the action gets underway, none of that matters. You don't need to understand the first half of the film to enjoy the second.
The cast is bland and forgettable, and veteran B-lister Robert Forster even looks embarrassed to be in this. It's a pretty silly performance and a lame part to begin with. But, if you can make it past the mystifying, completely unnecessary opening half, there are some enjoyable moments here. The special effects are quite remarkable considering what the filmmakers had to work with. The battle sequences are a blast, and so much better than the big-budget "Godzilla" remake. 
I just wonder why the makers of "Dragon Wars" felt the need to lull us to sleep first. There are some laughs, but mostly blank stares and puzzled looks. The script is needlessly complicated and overly plotted for what the writers set out to accomplish. It's ambitious, but to what avail?

D-War, I must admit, is the best giant snake movie since Boa versus Python. I say this with no disrespect to BvP which is truly a misunderstood sub-genre classic.

But back to D-War. The film deserves credit for its sheer audacity alone. Not only do we have a giant snake ripping things up from feudal Korea to modern day America, but he also has at his disposal an army of black armoured soldiers (think the Uruk-Hai from Lord of the Rings on a tight budget) who ride around on the backs of dinosaurs... with rocket launchers!


While the storyline is a bit off-the-wall (referencing obscure Korean legends), it is somewhat refreshing to watch a film about a giant monster that is not an alien visitor run amuck or a result of genetic engineering gone awry. The special effects are mostly solid, if not spectacular. Indeed there are times when they get a little bit ropey. However, the budget of  D-War budget was fairly low for a film of its kind so this is forgivable as the film is a fairly impressive technical achievement overall.

Enough of that!, I hear you say, Tell us about the action! Well, I am happy to say that for the most part it delivers. The first act contains some fairly cool over the top kung fu fighting that looks, how shall we say, inspired by Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon. Toward the end there is a great battle between the dinosaur people and the US army in a busy city which packs a nice punch. There is also one of those epic CGI showdowns to cap off the finale. Unfortunately the pacing of the middle of the film is a bit too slow, consisting of several chase scenes (apparently the only weakness of a Demi-God snake monster is to drive away from it very quickly) and some hammy detective work. Luckily it does not take itself too seriously, offering some goofy humour every now and then to keep the tone light and stop the film from becoming too dependent on a lacklustre storyline.

Overall, D-War is an enjoyable romp well worth checking out if you are up late and in the mood for some B-movie style action.
